title: My Husband's Ingenious Trick for Making "Life-Changing" Guacamole
author: Kristina Razon
text: SkillsTips & TechniquesKristina RazonDeputy Food EditorI’m the Deputy Food Editor at The Kitchn. Previously, I was an editor at Serious Eats for close to three years. Before that, I spent a decade cooking and baking in professional kitchens. My writing focuses on all things food — mostly dinners and desserts, fun cocktails, and hot tips. published yesterdayWe independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.Credit: Photo: Ryan Liebe ; Food Stylist: Brett RegotTaco Tuesdays are a regular occurrence in my home. We keep it pretty simple: There’s always seasoned ground beef and more than enough guacamole to go around (along with chopped tomatoes, sour cream, and shredded cheese). While I cook dinner most nights, my husband oversees taco night. With the help of our 7-year old son, they’ll divvy up the prep. My husband handles anything that involves the stovetop and oven, while our kid picks cilantro leaves and chops tomatoes with his plastic serrated knife. A few months ago when it was time to mash the avocados for guacamole, I overheard our son asking what he should use to do just that. My husband replied, “How about this potato masher?” I headed to the kitchen to intervene, but once I got there, he was already mashing those avocados like a pro. The rest is history. How It WorksMost guacamole recipes will instruct you to use the back of a fork to smash avocados until they reach a chunky consistency. I never questioned that logic — using a fork just made sense. It wasn’t until I tried mashing avocados with a potato masher that it clicked. Think about it: A potato masher is basically just a giant back of a fork, giving you more surface area for mashing all those avocados in one go. It was quicker, easier, and (if I’m being honest) more fun than using a fork. Tips for Making Guacamole with a Potato Masher It works best if you’re mashing at least three avocados. This method works well if you need to smash a large amount of avocados, as there should be enough for the potato masher to work with.  Use a bowl with a wide, flat bottom. Because the potato masher takes up more space than a fork, you’ll want to use a bowl that can accommodate its size. It’s best to use one with a wide, flat bottom to ensure that every prong makes even contact with the bottom of the bowl.
html:
• Skills
  • Tips & Techniques

Kristina RazonDeputy Food Editor

I’m the Deputy Food Editor at The Kitchn. Previously, I was an editor at Serious Eats for close to three years. Before that, I spent a decade cooking and baking in professional kitchens. My writing focuses on all things food — mostly dinners and desserts, fun cocktails, and hot tips.

published yesterday

We independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.

Taco Tuesdays are a regular occurrence in my home. We keep it pretty simple: There’s always seasoned ground beef and more than enough guacamole to go around (along with chopped tomatoes, sour cream, and shredded cheese). While I cook dinner most nights, my husband oversees taco night. With the help of our 7-year old son, they’ll divvy up the prep. My husband handles anything that involves the stovetop and oven, while our kid picks cilantro leaves and chops tomatoes with his plastic serrated knife. 

A few months ago when it was time to mash the avocados for guacamole, I overheard our son asking what he should use to do just that. My husband replied, “How about this potato masher?” I headed to the kitchen to intervene, but once I got there, he was already mashing those avocados like a pro. The rest is history. 

How It Works

Most guacamole recipes will instruct you to use the back of a fork to smash avocados until they reach a chunky consistency. I never questioned that logic — using a fork just made sense. It wasn’t until I tried mashing avocados with a potato masher that it clicked. Think about it: A potato masher is basically just a giant back of a fork, giving you more surface area for mashing all those avocados in one go. It was quicker, easier, and (if I’m being honest) more fun than using a fork. 

Tips for Making Guacamole with a Potato Masher

  • It works best if you’re mashing at least three avocados. This method works well if you need to smash a large amount of avocados, as there should be enough for the potato masher to work with. 
  • Use a bowl with a wide, flat bottom. Because the potato masher takes up more space than a fork, you’ll want to use a bowl that can accommodate its size. It’s best to use one with a wide, flat bottom to ensure that every prong makes even contact with the bottom of the bowl.
